bibl.idno: The Papers of Henry Rose Carter [manuscript] ; HEALTHSCI MS-10.

bibl.title: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to Joseph A. LePrince, August 17, 1928

div1.p: [Carter] writes LePrince to ask for his input on the bibliography to the History of Yellow Fever.

div1.head: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to Joseph A. LePrince, August 17, 1928
div1.opener:
Carbon copy
Book
Bib.
LePrince
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
August 17, 1928.
Dear Mr. LePrince:
div1.p:
I wonder if you will be so very kind as to help me out
with the enclosed bibliography, so far as field work will permit? As
you may see, my references are very incomplete, which makes them extremely
hard to find, when there are so many journals in which they might have
appeared. I especially want your bibliography--i. e. every publication
in which you mention the occasional occurrence of aegypti larvae in street
gutters. I think there is another ref. to some article of yours re aegypti
breeding (in winter) in some hotel, but I have not access to my files to-day
Will you please give me this ref also “per si [unclear]?”

Of course, I don't expect you to be able to help me with all of
the enclosed references, but any that you can give will be a god-send and
perhaps Dr. Barber might have some literature available which you haven't.

I am hoping and praying that I will get my references in such
shape that I can go over to Baltimore next month and take them to Frost, in
order that he may do the final editing of Father's MSS before we send it
in to the I. H. D. for publication. which we hope to do in November. I wish much that the early publication
of Father's book were not so very important, as (despite the time that has
already been spent on it) I should like to spend the whole of next winter
on winding it up as he would have liked to have it. However, it is needed
now as “ammunition” so I've been working from seven to ten hours per diem
on it ever since I got back from the Hopkins last March (after two months
there on account of “flu.”) I have a wonderful Secretary (one of the staff
of the Library of Congress) and she and I, after two and a half months at
the aforesaid Library checking “pre-historic” references to yellow fever in
six languages, are now at the Library of the S. G. of the Army working up
the purely medical references. These are dreadful as Father knew them all
so well that he didn't record them in his bibliographic notes. Had he done
so we had finished e'er now. As it is, things that he could have cleared up
up for me
-2-
in a few hours will take us as many weeks. However, Father was wise to
stick to the text of his MSS, which no one else could do, and leave the
“mechanics” to the future. We just finished as it was!

I think so often of “the Malaria Gang” and hope sometime to see you
during your flying visits to Washington.

With all manner of remembrances to each one of you, and also to
your family, I remaiin
div1.closer:
Most truly your friend, Senior Sanitary Engineer J. A. LePrince,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Office of Field Investigations of Malaria,
Richmond, Va.
Please forward.
P. S. I got a note from Theodore Hayne just before he sailed
for West Africa. I don't balame him for going, but I hope that the Service
will get him eventually.
1 enclosure.
